items.title: Beyond Content: How Author Network Centrality Drives Citation Disparities in Top AI Conferences
items.authors: Renlong Jie, Longfeng Zhao, Chen Chu, Danyang Jia, Zhen Wang
items.institution: Northwestern Polytechnical University, Yunnan University of Finance and Economics
items.contributions: 1. Proposed a novel centrality metric (Harmonic Closeness with Temporal and Collaboration Count Decay - HCTCD) that incorporates temporal decay and collaboration intensity. 2. Advanced the methodological field by employing beta regression to model citation percentiles, appropriately handling the bounded nature of citation data. 3. Demonstrated that team-level centrality aggregation, particularly through exponentially weighted summation, explains citation variance more effectively than individual or rank-based approaches, highlighting the importance of collective network connectivity.
items.summary: This study investigates how authors' positions in scientific collaboration networks influence citation disparities in top AI conferences. It proposes a new centrality metric (HCTCD) and uses beta regression to analyze data from NeurIPS, ICML, and ICLR. The findings show that long-term network centrality, especially at the team level, is a strong predictor of citations, challenging evaluation paradigms that focus solely on content.

items.title: Intelligent Knowledge Mining Framework: Bridging AI Analysis and Trustworthy Preservation
items.summary: The paper proposes the Intelligent Knowledge Mining Framework (IKMF), a conceptual dual-stream architecture that combines a horizontal AI-driven mining process with a parallel trustworthy archiving stream. It aims to bridge the gap between dynamic analysis and long-term preservation, transforming static data repositories into living, actionable knowledge ecosystems.
